message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest PCP intoxication, with agitation, bizarre behavior, and ocular nystagmus. Other options may cause similar symptoms but do not fit the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation, including agitation, bizarre behavior, and nystagmus, is consistent with PCP intoxication. Cocaine intoxication may also cause agitation but typically presents with increased heart rate and blood pressure. Central nervous system infection and serotonin syndrome do not typically present with these specific symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest PCP intoxication, which includes agitation, hallucinations, and delirium. Cocaine may cause agitation and heart rate increase, but not nystagmus and bizarre behavior. Central nervous system infection usually starts with fever and headache. Serotonin syndrome presents with hyperthermia, clonus, and hyperreflexia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's bizarre behavior, nystagmus, and difficulty with coordination suggest PCP intoxication. Cocaine intoxication may cause agitation but not the other symptoms present. Central nervous system infection and serotonin syndrome also do not fit the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s behavior, including agitation, paranoid delusions, and hallucinations, suggests a possible PCP intoxication. Mild horizontal nystagmus is also commonly seen in PCP intoxication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including agitation, bizarre behavior, and hallucination, suggest intoxication with a psychotic drug. Among the options, Phencyclidine (PCP) is most likely to cause these symptoms. The ocular exam finding of mild horizontal nystagmus is also consistent with PCP intoxication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms in line with Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication. These symptoms include agitation, bizarre behavior, nystagmus, drooling, and difficulty with coordination. The fact that the patient was found naked in the street is also suggestive of drug-induced psychosis. Cocaine intoxication can cause agitation and elevated blood pressure, but it typically does not cause hallucinations or bizarre behavior. Central nervous system infections and serotonin syndrome are less likely given the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation suggests intoxication with Phencyclidine (PCP) which can cause agitation, hallucinations, nystagmus, and ataxia. Cocaine intoxication can cause similar symptoms but not the bizarre behavior and hallucinations. Central nervous system infection and serotonin syndrome do not fit the presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of agitation, bizarre behavior, and hallucinations are all consistent with Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication. The horizontal nystagmus and difficulty with coordination also support this diagnosis. The other options do not fully describe the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest hallucinations and agitation, which are common in Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication. The ocular exam is also significant for mild horizontal nystagmus, which is a common feature of PCP intoxication. Cocaine intoxication can cause agitation and hallucinations, but it’s less likely to cause the specific symptom of nystagmus. Central nervous system infection and serotonin syndrome are also not likely to cause this specific combination of symptoms.
